slides.title: Welcome to Algebra! üî§
slides.content:
Algebra is like a mathematical puzzle where letters stand for unknown numbers. It's actually easier than it sounds!

In this lesson, you'll learn:

  • What variables are and why we use them
  • How to write and read algebraic expressions
  • The order of operations (PEMDAS/BODMAS)
  • How to solve simple equations
  • Real-world algebra applications
slides.tip: Think of algebra as a mystery game - you're a detective finding the value of the unknown number!

slides.title: What is Algebra?
slides.content:
Algebra uses letters (variables) to represent numbers we don't know yet.

Why use algebra?

  • To solve problems with unknown values
  • To write general rules that work for any number
  • To describe relationships between quantities

Common Variables:

  • x, y, z - most common variables
  • n - often used for unknown numbers
  • a, b, c - used for known numbers (constants)
slides.example:
Example:

Instead of saying: "I have some money and my friend gave me GH‚Çµ5, now I have GH‚Çµ15"

Algebra says: x + 5 = 15

  • x = the money you started with
  • 5 = money your friend gave you
  • 15 = total money now

We can solve: x = 15 - 5 = 10

You started with GH‚Çµ10!

slides.title: Algebraic Expressions
slides.content:
An algebraic expression is a combination of numbers, variables, and operations (+, ‚àí, √ó, √∑).

Parts of an expression:

  • Terms: Parts separated by + or ‚àí
  • Coefficient: The number in front of a variable
  • Variable: The letter representing an unknown
  • Constant: A number by itself

Example: 3x + 5

  • 2 terms: "3x" and "5"
  • Coefficient: 3
  • Variable: x
  • Constant: 5
slides.example:
Reading Expressions:

  • 2x = "two times x" or "two x"
  • x + 7 = "x plus seven"
  • 3y - 4 = "three y minus four"
  • 5n = "five times n" or "five n"

Writing Expressions:

  • "A number plus 8" = x + 8
  • "Three times a number" = 3n
  • "A number minus 5" = x - 5
slides.tip: When a number and variable are next to each other (like 3x), it always means multiplication!

slides.title: Order of Operations (BODMAS)
slides.content:
When solving expressions, follow the BODMAS rule (or PEMDAS):

Brackets (Parentheses)

Orders (Exponents/Powers)

Division

Multiplication

Addition

Subtraction

Important: Division and Multiplication have equal priority (left to right). Same for Addition and Subtraction.
slides.example:
Example: 5 + 3 √ó 4

WRONG: 5 + 3 = 8, then 8 √ó 4 = 32 ‚ùå

RIGHT: 3 √ó 4 = 12, then 5 + 12 = 17 ‚úì

Example with Brackets: (5 + 3) √ó 4

Step 1: Brackets first ‚Üí 5 + 3 = 8

Step 2: Multiply ‚Üí 8 √ó 4 = 32

Answer: 32

Practice: 20 ‚àí 2 √ó 3 + 4

2 √ó 3 = 6 ‚Üí 20 ‚àí 6 + 4 = 18
slides.tip: Remember: Please Excuse My Dear Aunt Sally (PEMDAS) or Brackets Orders Division Multiplication Addition Subtraction (BODMAS)!

slides.title: Solving Simple Equations
slides.content:
An equation is like a balanced scale - both sides are equal.

Goal: Get the variable alone on one side

Golden Rule: Whatever you do to one side, do to the other!

Steps to solve:

  1. Identify what's attached to the variable
  2. Use opposite operations to isolate the variable
  3. Check your answer by substituting back

Opposite Operations:

  • Addition ‚Üî Subtraction
  • Multiplication ‚Üî Division
slides.example:
Example: x + 7 = 15

Step 1: 7 is added to x

Step 2: Subtract 7 from both sides

x + 7 ‚àí 7 = 15 ‚àí 7

x = 8

Step 3: Check: 8 + 7 = 15 ‚úì

Example: 3x = 12

Step 1: x is multiplied by 3

Step 2: Divide both sides by 3

3x √∑ 3 = 12 √∑ 3

x = 4

Step 3: Check: 3 √ó 4 = 12 ‚úì

slides.title: Two-Step Equations
slides.content:
Some equations need two steps to solve.

Strategy: Work backwards using order of operations

Steps:

  1. First, undo addition/subtraction
  2. Then, undo multiplication/division

Think of it like unwrapping a gift - remove outer layers first!
slides.example:
Example: 2x + 5 = 13

Step 1: Subtract 5 from both sides

2x + 5 ‚àí 5 = 13 ‚àí 5

2x = 8

Step 2: Divide both sides by 2

2x √∑ 2 = 8 √∑ 2

x = 4

Check: 2(4) + 5 = 8 + 5 = 13 ‚úì

Another Example: 3x ‚àí 7 = 11

Step 1: Add 7 ‚Üí 3x = 18

Step 2: Divide by 3 ‚Üí x = 6

slides.title: Algebra in Real Life
slides.content:
Algebra helps solve everyday problems:

  • Shopping: "I bought 3 items at the same price and spent GH‚Çµ45. What was the price per item?"
  • Equation: 3x = 45, so x = GH‚Çµ15
  • Sharing: "I have some money. After giving my sister GH‚Çµ10, I have GH‚Çµ25 left. How much did I start with?"
  • Equation: x ‚àí 10 = 25, so x = GH‚Çµ35
  • Travel: "A taxi charges GH‚Çµ5 base fare plus GH‚Çµ2 per kilometer. I paid GH‚Çµ19. How far did I travel?"
  • Equation: 5 + 2x = 19, so x = 7 kilometers
slides.example:
Practice Problem:

"You save the same amount each week. After 4 weeks, you have GH‚Çµ80. How much do you save per week?"

Solution:

Let x = weekly savings

4x = 80

x = 80 √∑ 4

x = GH‚Çµ20 per week
slides.tip: When solving word problems, first translate the story into an equation!

slides.content:
